qas.question: Why did European powers lay claim to areas Africa?

answers.text: exhibit a sphere of influence over the area

qas.question: What did the European powers need to make their claim over these areas legitimate?

answers.text: These claims did not have to have any substantial land holdings or treaties to be legitimate.

qas.question: What do European powers that exibit their control ovet an area accept?

answers.text: mandate to rule that region as a national colony.

qas.question: How did the claims on the areas in Africa benefit the European powers?

answers.text: colony’s commercial interests without having to fear rival European competition.

qas.question: What was the colonial experience for Africans described as?

context: The major European powers laid claim to the areas of Africa where they could <a0_0>exhibit a sphere of influence over the area<a0_0/>. <a1_0>These claims did not have to have any substantial land holdings or treaties to be legitimate.<a1_0/> The European power that demonstrated its control over a territory accepted the <a2_0>mandate to rule that region as a national colony.<a2_0/> The European nation that held the claim developed and benefited from their <a3_0>colony’s commercial interests without having to fear rival European competition.<a3_0/> With the colonial claim came the underlying assumption that the European power that exerted control would use its mandate to offer protection and provide welfare for its colonial peoples, however, this principle remained more theory than practice. There were many documented instances of material and moral conditions deteriorating for native Africans in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries under European colonial rule, to the point where the colonial experience for them has been described as "<a4_0>hell on earth.<a4_0/>"
